title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement max@rstudio.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Using characterize with tidymodels
text: Let’s fit regression tree data: Fit particular model, aspects model can quantified using characterize(): values can help understand complexity model. aspect determined individual functions start .pluck, .pluck_num_active_features(). Almost functions return numeric values. one exception can return predictors functionally used prediction equation: Different models return different types model characteristics return :
code: cart_fit <-    decision_tree(cost_complexity = 0.05) %>%    set_mode("regression") %>%    fit(outcome ~ ., data = sim_train) cart_fit ## parsnip model object ##  ## n= 1000  ##  ## node), split, n, deviance, yval ##       * denotes terminal node ##  ##  1) root 1000 675.56010  0.132640600   ##    2) predictor_03< 0.4294012 401 169.56340 -0.398818000   ##      4) predictor_07>=0.3936169 247  88.29824 -0.650205000 * ##      5) predictor_07< 0.3936169 154  40.62021  0.004380685 * ##    3) predictor_03>=0.4294012 599 316.91210  0.488425100   ##      6) predictor_01< 0.5095151 306  92.81308  0.204690200 * ##      7) predictor_01>=0.5095151 293 173.73660  0.784749000   ##       14) predictor_02< 0.674366 182  55.90145  0.472063700 * ##       15) predictor_02>=0.674366 111  70.86405  1.297440000 * characterize(cart_fit) ## # A tibble: 2 × 3 ##   .metric             .estimator .estimate ##   <chr>               <chr>          <dbl> ## 1 num_active_features model              4 ## 2 num_term_nodes      model              5 .pluck_active_features(cart_fit) ## # A tibble: 1 × 2 ##   statistic       value     ##   <chr>           <list>    ## 1 active_features <chr [4]> # to get them:  .pluck_active_features(cart_fit) %>%    unnest(value) ## # A tibble: 4 × 2 ##   statistic       value        ##   <chr>           <chr>        ## 1 active_features predictor_01 ## 2 active_features predictor_02 ## 3 active_features predictor_03 ## 4 active_features predictor_07 ppr(outcome ~ ., data = sim_train, nterms = 3) %>%    characterize() ## # A tibble: 0 × 3 ## # … with 3 variables: .metric <chr>, .estimator <chr>, .estimate <dbl>

title: Using characterize with tidymodels
text: night want know characteristics related model performance. Let’s tune model. cost-complexity parameter (aka Cp) modulated 20 different values. models fit 10 resamples data. tuning functions tidymodels option return fitted models (results based models). extract option control functions can used define returned. ’ll use retain_characteristics() function. execute characterize() models. Note now column called .extracts. resample corresponding tibble 20 rows: open help files tidyr::unnest(), stop reading, helper function put results usable format: values mean column average characteristics. option called summarize can indicate individual model results returned. relationship tuning parameter characteristics?  great probably want know characteristics relate model performance. Another option, add_metrics = TRUE also collect performance metrics (RMSE R2) row-bound previous results.  Another way pivot performance metrics columns. , can plot versus performance:  Recall 10 informative predictors. Selecting results sudden severe -fitting. Keeping many model results slow degradation performance. One thing might also desire know “’s minimum number features give RMSE less 0.55?”
code: cart_spec <-    decision_tree(cost_complexity = tune()) %>%    set_mode("regression")  ctrl <- control_grid(extract = retain_characteristics)  cart_res <-   cart_spec %>%   tune_grid(     outcome ~ .,     resamples = sim_rs,     grid = tibble(cost_complexity = 10 ^ seq(-4, -1, length.out = 20)),     control = ctrl   ) cart_res ## # Tuning results ## # 10-fold cross-validation  ## # A tibble: 10 × 5 ##    splits            id     .metrics          .notes           .extracts         ##    <list>            <chr>  <list>            <list>           <list>            ##  1 <split [900/100]> Fold01 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ##  2 <split [900/100]> Fold02 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ##  3 <split [900/100]> Fold03 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ##  4 <split [900/100]> Fold04 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ##  5 <split [900/100]> Fold05 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ##  6 <split [900/100]> Fold06 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ##  7 <split [900/100]> Fold07 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ##  8 <split [900/100]> Fold08 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ##  9 <split [900/100]> Fold09 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> ## 10 <split [900/100]> Fold10 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]> cart_res$.extracts[[1]] %>% head() ## # A tibble: 6 × 3 ##   cost_complexity .extracts        .config               ##             <dbl> <list>           <chr>                 ## 1        0.0001   <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model01 ## 2        0.000144 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model02 ## 3        0.000207 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model03 ## 4        0.000298 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model04 ## 5        0.000428 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model05 ## 6        0.000616 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model06 # Getting closer: cart_res$.extracts[[1]]$.extracts[[1]] ## # A tibble: 1 × 1 ##   results          ##   <list>           ## 1 <tibble [2 × 3]> # The actual results:  cart_res$.extracts[[1]]$.extracts[[1]]$results ## [[1]] ## # A tibble: 2 × 3 ##   .metric             .estimator .estimate ##   <chr>               <chr>          <dbl> ## 1 num_active_features model             26 ## 2 num_term_nodes      model             76 model_char <- collect_characteristics(cart_res) model_char ## # A tibble: 40 × 7 ##    cost_complexity .metric             .estimator  mean     n std_err .config    ##              <dbl> <chr>               <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>      ##  1        0.0001   num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces… ##  2        0.0001   num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces… ##  3        0.000144 num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces… ##  4        0.000144 num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces… ##  5        0.000207 num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces… ##  6        0.000207 num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces… ##  7        0.000298 num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces… ##  8        0.000298 num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces… ##  9        0.000428 num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces… ## 10        0.000428 num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces… ## # … with 30 more rows model_char %>%    ggplot(aes(cost_complexity, mean)) +    geom_point() +    geom_line(alpha = 1 / 2) +    facet_wrap(~ .metric, scales = "free_y") +    scale_x_log10() +   labs(y = NULL) metric_and_char <- collect_characteristics(cart_res, add_metrics = TRUE) metric_and_char ## # A tibble: 80 × 7 ##    cost_complexity .metric             .estimator   mean     n std_err .config   ##              <dbl> <chr>               <chr>       <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>     ##  1        0.0001   num_active_features model      26.7      10 1.16    Preproce… ##  2        0.0001   num_term_nodes      model      73.4      10 1.03    Preproce… ##  3        0.0001   rmse                standard    0.542    10 0.00753 Preproce… ##  4        0.0001   rsq                 standard    0.587    10 0.0191  Preproce… ##  5        0.000144 num_active_features model      26.7      10 1.16    Preproce… ##  6        0.000144 num_term_nodes      model      73.4      10 1.03    Preproce… ##  7        0.000144 rmse                standard    0.542    10 0.00753 Preproce… ##  8        0.000144 rsq                 standard    0.587    10 0.0191  Preproce… ##  9        0.000207 num_active_features model      26.7      10 1.16    Preproce… ## 10        0.000207 num_term_nodes      model      73.4      10 1.03    Preproce… ## # … with 70 more rows metric_and_char %>%    ggplot(aes(cost_complexity, mean)) +    geom_point() +    geom_line(alpha = 1 / 2) +    facet_wrap(~ .metric, scales = "free_y") +    scale_x_log10()+   labs(y = NULL) rmse_vs_vars <- collect_characteristics(cart_res, add_metrics = TRUE, wide = TRUE) rmse_vs_vars %>% head() ## # A tibble: 6 × 6 ##   cost_complexity num_active_features num_term_nodes  rmse   rsq .config         ##             <dbl>               <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>           ## 1        0.0001                  26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_… ## 2        0.000144                26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_… ## 3        0.000207                26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_… ## 4        0.000298                26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_… ## 5        0.000428                26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_… ## 6        0.000616                26.5           72.6 0.541 0.588 Preprocessor1_… rmse_vs_vars %>%   ggplot(aes(num_active_features, rmse)) +    geom_point() +    geom_line(alpha = 1 / 2) +   geom_hline(yintercept = 0.55, lty = 2, col = "green") rmse_vs_vars %>%    filter(rmse <= 0.55) %>%    slice_min(num_active_features, n = 1) ## # A tibble: 1 × 6 ##   cost_complexity num_active_features num_term_nodes  rmse   rsq .config         ##             <dbl>               <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>           ## 1         0.00546                 7.4           24.9 0.540 0.571 Preprocessor1_…

title: Authors and Citation

code: @Manual{,   title = {characterize: Characteristics of a Fitted Model},   author = {Max Kuhn},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

title: Characteristics of a Fitted Model
text: goal characterize report data driven characteristics model fit describe model. example: number predictors used, number terminal nodes, . interesting characteristics model often reflect complexity model.

title: Characteristics of a Fitted Model
text: can install development version characterize like :

title: Characteristics of a Fitted Model
text: basic example shows solve common problem: Objects least one method: bagger, bart, brulee_mlp, C5.0, cforest, cubist, earth, glmnet, ksvm, lgb.Booster, mixo_pls, mixo_plsda, mixo_spls, mixo_splsda, multinom, nnet, party, partynode, ranger, rpart, terms, xgb.Booster, xrf.
code: library(characterize) library(rpart)  cart_mod <- rpart(mpg ~ ., data = mtcars) cart_mod #> n= 32  #>  #> node), split, n, deviance, yval #>       * denotes terminal node #>  #> 1) root 32 1126.04700 20.09062   #>   2) cyl>=5 21  198.47240 16.64762   #>     4) hp>=192.5 7   28.82857 13.41429 * #>     5) hp< 192.5 14   59.87214 18.26429 * #>   3) cyl< 5 11  203.38550 26.66364 *  characterize(cart_mod) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   .metric             .estimator .estimate #>   <chr>               <chr>          <dbl> #> 1 num_active_features model              2 #> 2 num_term_nodes      model              3  # Also some low-level functions:  .pluck_active_features(cart_mod) %>%    tidyr::unnest(value) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   statistic       value #>   <chr>           <chr> #> 1 active_features cyl   #> 2 active_features hp

title: Characteristics of a Fitted Model
text: Please note characterize project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Compute model characteristics — characterize
text: characterize() attempts report data driven characteristics model fit describe model. example, number predictors used, number terminal nodes, etc. interesting characteristics model often reflect complexity model.

title: Compute model characteristics — characterize
code: characterize(x, ...)  # S3 method for default characterize(x, ...)  # S3 method for model_fit characterize(x, ...)  # S3 method for workflow characterize(x, ...)  # S3 method for glmnet characterize(x, penalty = 0.001, ...)  # S3 method for cubist characterize(x, committees = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for tidy_cubist characterize(x, committees = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for cubist characterize(x, committees = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for tidy_C50 characterize(x, trials = max(x$trials), ...)  # S3 method for C5.0 characterize(x, trials = x$trials["Actual"], ...)  # S3 method for xgb.Booster characterize(x, nrounds = x$niter, ...)  # S3 method for tidy_xrf characterize(x, penalty = 0.001, ...)  # S3 method for xrf characterize(x, penalty = 0.001, ...)  # S3 method for lgb.Booster characterize(x, trees = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for fda characterize(x, ...)

title: Compute model characteristics — characterize
text: x object. ... currently used. penalty numeric parameter value amount regularization/penalty model. committees number Cubist committees use examination. trials, nrounds, trees number boosting use examination.

title: Compute model characteristics — characterize
text: tibble columns .metric, .estimator, .estimate. statistics compute, zero-row tibble returned. Integer values converted double.

title: Compute model characteristics — characterize
text: list object types supported, see list_characteristics().

title: Compute model characteristics — characterize
code: library(rpart) cart_mod <- rpart(mpg ~ ., data = mtcars) characterize(cart_mod) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   .metric             .estimator .estimate #>   <chr>               <chr>          <dbl> #> 1 num_active_features model              2 #> 2 num_term_nodes      model              3  # When there is nothing to report: ppr_mod <- ppr(mpg ~ ., data = mtcars, nterms = 5) characterize(ppr_mod) #> # A tibble: 0 × 3 #> # … with 3 variables: .metric <chr>, .estimator <chr>, .estimate <dbl>

what: Show lists of models and characteristics — list_characteristics
title: Show lists of models and characteristics — list_characteristics
text: Show lists models characteristics

title: Show lists of models and characteristics — list_characteristics
Show lists of models and characteristics — list_characteristics
text: list_characteristics() returns tibble columns characteristic object. object_list() returns character string.

what: Model characterizations across multiple configurations — multi_characterize
title: Model characterizations across multiple configurations — multi_characterize
text: models can make predictions multiple configurations using model object. example, many boosted tree models using m trees can also make predictions fewer m trees used. sometimes called "sub-model parameters". model, multi_characterize() can produce multiple results object. model allow , results characterize() returned.

title: Model characterizations across multiple configurations — multi_characterize
code: multi_characterize(object, ...)  # S3 method for default multi_characterize(object, ...)  # S3 method for workflow multi_characterize(object, ...)  # S3 method for model_fit multi_characterize(object, ...)  # S3 method for `_elnet` multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for glmnet multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for `_multnet` multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for multnet multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for `_lognet` multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for lognet multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for `_fishnet` multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for fishnet multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for cubist multi_characterize(object, committees = object$committees, ...)  # S3 method for C5.0 multi_characterize(object, trials = object$trials["Actual"], ...)  # S3 method for xgb.Booster multi_characterize(object, nrounds = object$niter, ...)  # S3 method for xrf multi_characterize(object, penalty = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for lgb_trees multi_characterize(object, trees = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for lgb.Booster multi_characterize(object, trees = NULL, ...)

title: Model characterizations across multiple configurations — multi_characterize
text: object model_fit object. ... Optional arguments (currently used) penalty numeric parameter value amount regularization/penalty model. committees number Cubist committees use examination. trials, nrounds, trees number boosting use examination.

title: Model characterizations across multiple configurations — multi_characterize
text: tibble characterized results (results) extra columns sub-model parameter. specific multi_characterize() method, parameter columns results column results using basic characterize() call.

title: Model characterizations across multiple configurations — multi_characterize
text: glmnet models, methods different classes model (.k.. lognet class Poisson models) well variation class (_lognet). latter case corresponds object produced parsnip package model.

title: Model characterizations across multiple configurations — multi_characterize
code: if (FALSE) { # characterize:::is_rcmd_check() if (rlang::is_installed(c("modeldata", "ggplot2", "Cubist"))) {   library(Cubist)   library(dplyr)   library(ggplot2)   library(tidyr)    # ----------------------------------------------------------------------------    data(ames, package = "modeldata")   ames$Sale_Price <- log10(ames$Sale_Price)    cubist_fit <-     cubist(x = ames %>% select(-Sale_Price), y = ames$Sale_Price, committees = 5)    # ----------------------------------------------------------------------------   # Get results for a specific model configuration    characterize(cubist_fit, committees = 3)    # ----------------------------------------------------------------------------   # Get results for many model configurations    res <- multi_characterize(cubist_fit, committees = 1:5)   res    # unnest to use them:   res %>%     unnest(cols = results) %>%     ggplot(aes(committees, .estimate)) +     geom_point() +     facet_wrap(~ .metric, scale = "free_y") } }

title: Predictors used in the model — pluck_active_features
code: .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for default .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for workflow .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for model_fit .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for terms .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for rpart .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for ranger .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for xgb.Booster .pluck_active_features(x, nrounds = x$niter, ...)  # S3 method for glmnet .pluck_active_features(x, penalty = 0.001, ...)  # S3 method for tidy_cubist .pluck_active_features(x, committees = max(x$committee), ...)  # S3 method for cubist .pluck_active_features(x, committees = x$committees, ...)  # S3 method for tidy_C50 .pluck_active_features(x, trials = max(x$trial), ...)  # S3 method for C5.0 .pluck_active_features(x, trials = x$trials["Actual"], ...)  # S3 method for earth .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for mixo_spls .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for mixo_pls .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for mixo_splsda .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for mixo_plsda .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for bagger .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for bart .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for party .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for cforest .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for tidy_xrf .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for xrf .pluck_active_features(x, penalty = 0.001, ...)  # S3 method for bagger .pluck_active_features(x, ...)  # S3 method for lgb_trees .pluck_active_features(x, trees = max(x$trees), ...)  # S3 method for lgb.Booster .pluck_active_features(x, trees = x$params$num_iterations, ...)
